Comedians like Alina Pușcău, a veteran of Romanian Comedy TV or Andreea Bălan and her Cuc Arde In Vara crew were huge successes by that time. Latter Days is a very, VERY independent movie. And compared to many of today's more modern films, it's lacking on many parts. The shooting budget was very cheap and the overall movie is not meant to be intense or full of confetti throwing, party smacking scenes. Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. The movie is divided into two parts; the beginning sees Miyazawa and his friends enjoying a good life out in nature, before his childhood friend is damaged in an accident. In the second half of the film, his friend helps Miyazawa enter a new lifestyle as a tinker with his shop and inventions.<|end_of_text|>

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was released as "Going Places" in the U.S. to keep folks from sticking their foot in their mouth. Brother. I think I know a few sheepish enough to still do that.

If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. Directed by Republic's ace team of William Witney and John English and starring John Carroll, Eric Campbell, and George "Gabby" Hayes, Buffalo Bill, Jr. was originally released in 1945.

Ride, you brave son of the West

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The cat, whom Alice is allergic to, goes out of his way to terrorize the family. Well, until he ultimately meets his match when he runs into an elderly man with an eye patch and cane with a strong dislike for him.
This is a low-budget slasher/horror film of the kind
